messages.message:
Hi all, I have an observation on accuracy testing & definitions in AI Hub. I see the formula for validated accuracy is *# of automated and correct fields / all fields*.

This is different from how we've traditionally defined validated accuracy with customers during POVs and solution builds. We've taken the approach of *# of automated and correct fields / total automated fields.* Unless we've changed our approach with scoring POVs, this may be confusing to prospects/customers FYI @Jasper.

Additionally, validated accuracy as it's defined in AI Hub (*# of automated and correct fields / all fields*) seems more like an STP metric rather than a pure accuracy metric. It's a measure of the % of fields that are automatically processed correctly.

^if these points hold up, then would it make sense to:
• introduce an additional metric to capture the accuracy of automated results (if this is still a core metric we use with customers)
• change the term for the current validated accuracy metric / align on terminology we use in the field vs in product

also even potentially remove the validated accuracy metric in its current form (*# of automated and correct fields / all fields*) as this is actually an STP metric, which are generally very harsh measures perform against
in the accuracy testing section of AI Hub. here's a screenshot
Ah okay, I'm pretty sure the graphic is incorrect then...

Ah you're right! I think the graphic is wrong (but our actual product calculation should be correct!). I agree the actual definition should be:

Validated accuracy = (# automated and correct) / (# Automated)
cc: @Serena @Liam Callanan if we can make a quick fix to this graphic
We just need the "Validated accuracy" title to be updated
